channel.title: All these languages...help?
channel.description:
Hey guys, just recently I've been interested in web page development. I already know Java so learning another language should come easier, however I'm real confused about all these languages and I don't know which to learn and which to skip.
First, these are all very noobified, dumbed down ways of describing these languages, but correct me if any of this is wrong please:
Html - Basic webpage making language. CSS - What gives the "spice" to a webpage (Color, fonts, images, etc.) JavaScript - A scipting language that allows you to create programs within a webpage. PHP - Another more popular scripting language? (This is where I get pretty confused) HTML5 - Combining both HTML, CSS and a scripting language into one? If someone could even give me a better idea of what a scripting language is, that would be wonderful.
Second, if anyone could direct me down a recommended path of learning webpage development, because I'm sure I don't need to know all of this. Lol.
Thanks.

item.title: All these languages...help?

Think of PHP as the actual programming language.
[/quote]
Please don’t. You’re bringing real programming languages to shame by doing this.[/quote]lol i love you

Read full topic

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Seperate a website into two components: a font-end and a back-end.

The front-end is the parts of a website you see infront of you, such as the actual template and dynamic features. This goes under HTML/XHTML/HTML5/etc…, CSS, and Javascript. The HTML is the page markup, this basically sets up the DOM, which can be manipulated by Javascript using your browser’s DOM API. With this capability, Javascript can be used to add extra, dynamic content to a seemingly dull page. CSS is basically the style to an HTML element (such as an anchor, image, and so on) you can apply to make your front-end look more appealing, and so everything fits together seamlessly on the page.

The back-end is what goes on server-side or “internally” to get a webpage running. Although it isn’t actually required to have a viewable webpage, you can use a language such as PHP, ASP, or web application frameworks like Ruby on Rails or Django as server-side languages and frameworks. The back-end process webpages before it is sent to a user. To more complete the list, commonly SQL is a language used in the back-end to query with a database, but this isn’t required in all back-ends.

Read full topic

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:
@Team_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:7, topic:450234”]If you only wish to create website templates, I suggest just learning HTML & CSS, but you must also have a familiarity with graphic design.

However, if you wish to create a lot of nice and nifty little tricks with your website, I suggest you use PHP. PHP is a very easy programming language to learn, but it is extremely useful. You should at least know the basics.

Also, along side PHP, you really should use MySQL, it only takes a day or so to learn, it’s definitely worth it.[/quote]

Solid advice right here.

Read full topic

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @Garbage_Breath Garbage Breath
item.description:
@Garbage_Breath wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:10, topic:450234”]No problem.

You’ll see there’s a lot of similarities between PHP and Java in the beginning stages, for example the use of if/else statements and switch statements, they’re exactly the same or more or less exactly the same. It’s easy enough to get started with. If you need any help, feel free to PM me.[/quote]

Awesome. Should be even easier to pick up on. Thanks, I’ll be sure to keep that in mind.

Read full topic

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

No problem.

You’ll see there’s a lot of similarities between PHP and Java in the beginning stages, for example the use of if/else statements and switch statements, they’re exactly the same or more or less exactly the same. It’s easy enough to get started with. If you need any help, feel free to PM me.

Read full topic

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @Garbage_Breath Garbage Breath
item.description:
@Garbage_Breath wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:7, topic:450234”]If you only wish to create website templates, I suggest just learning HTML & CSS, but you must also have a familiarity with graphic design.

However, if you wish to create a lot of nice and nifty little tricks with your website, I suggest you use PHP. PHP is a very easy programming language to learn, but it is extremely useful. You should at least know the basics.

Also, along side PHP, you really should use MySQL, it only takes a day or so to learn, it’s definitely worth it.[/quote]

[quote=“Whackatre, post:8, topic:450234”][quote author=Garbage Breath link=topic=553130.msg4052859#msg4052859 date=1342676947]

Cascading Style Sheets +

Meaning?

Think of PHP as the actual programming language.

Alright, what is it primarily used for?

Take a look yourself: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Php

CSS was invented to reduce the tediousness of HTML (I think).

Thanks man, one last thing. Would you recommend I learn this and Xhtml over Javascript or Html5? I’m not looking to learn every damn thing I just want a solid base for learning dynamic and efficient websites.
[/quote]

Well, HTML is pretty much the basis of every website. Try this yourself: visit a website and view its source code. I’m not a great web developer and I have never used XHTML, HTML5, and JS. If you want an efficient and dynamic websites, PHP (the actual programming) and MySQL (for data storage) are pretty much the only things you need (although I’m sure many people will beg to differ).[/quote]

Thanks guys, I think I have a better understanding of what to do. You guys gave me the little knowledge I needed to kickoff. Thank you

Read full topic

[/quote]

Thanks man, one last thing. Would you recommend I learn this and Xhtml over Javascript or Html5? I’m not looking to learn every damn thing I just want a solid base for learning dynamic and efficient websites.[/quote]

Well, HTML is pretty much the basis of every website. Try this yourself: visit a website and view its source code. I’m not a great web developer and I have never used XHTML, HTML5, and JS. If you want an efficient and dynamic websites, PHP (the actual programming) and MySQL (for data storage) are pretty much the only things you need (although I’m sure many people will beg to differ).

item.title: All these languages...help?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

If you only wish to create website templates, I suggest just learning HTML & CSS, but you must also have a familiarity with graphic design.

However, if you wish to create a lot of nice and nifty little tricks with your website, I suggest you use PHP. PHP is a very easy programming language to learn, but it is extremely useful. You should at least know the basics.

Also, along side PHP, you really should use MySQL, it only takes a day or so to learn, it’s definitely worth it.

Read full topic
